column1: One way that the brain makes sure to remember the events that are important to us is through specialized chemicals called neurotransmitters
column4: help build stronger memories. One such neurotransmitter is dopamine. Dopamine is released in the brain when something surprisingly good happens
column5: such as walking into class and finding a box of chocolates on your desk. When dopamine is released
column6: it strengthens memories. It does so by tagging these memories when they are created in a way that makes these memories slowly strengthen over time. This means that just as memories for unimportant things start fading away
column7: memories for important things grow stronger over time. In the end
column8: memories for these surprisingly good events can have greater influence over our behavior
column9: making it easier to use these memories to get the things we really want or need.A similar process takes place when especially bad things happen
column10: such as eating something that tastes terrible
column12: or other frightening events. This kind of fear learning depends on a specialized part of the brain
column14: which works together with the hippocampus to strengthen memories.
